action->Berserk.name: Berserk
action->Berserk.description: A severely damaged flesh golem has a chance of going berserk. If it has 8 or fewer HP at the start of its turn, the golem must succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:5] check or go berserk. A berserk golem wildly attacks the nearest living creature, or the nearest object if no creatures are nearby.

action->Electric Reflexes.name: Electric Reflexes
action->Electric Reflexes.description:
Trigger The golem takes electricity damage and a creature is adjacent to it

Effect The golem lashes out and tries to grab a nearby creature. The golem attempts an Athletics check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.PMbdMWc2QroouFGD]{Grapple} an adjacent creature. The creature also takes @Damage[1d4[electricity]] damage on a success, or @Damage[2d4[electricity]] damage on a critical success.

action->Golem Antimagic.name: Golem Antimagic
action->Golem Antimagic.description:
Harmed by fire (@Damage[2d6[untyped]], @Damage[1d4[untyped]] from areas and persistent damage); healed by electricity (area effects @Damage[1d4[healing]] HP); slowed by cold

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.GolemAntimagic]

action->Vulnerable to Flesh to Stone.name: Vulnerable to Flesh to Stone
action->Vulnerable to Flesh to Stone.description: Casting a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.znv4ECL7ZtuiagtA]{Petrify} spell on the golem affects it normally.

action->Berserk Slam.name: Berserk Slam
action->Berserk Slam.description:

Acid Spray Fountain.name: Acid Spray Fountain
Acid Spray Fountain.descriptionHazard: A concealed acid fountain with three nozzles is connected to eight pressure pads in the room.
Acid Spray Fountain.disable: @Check[thievery|dc:26|name:Disable the Fountain|traits:complex,mechanical,trap] (expert) on the fountain stops it from spraying acid, or @Check[thievery|dc:22|name:Disable a Fountain Nozzle|traits:complex,mechanical,trap] (expert) disables one of the nozzles and reduces the number of actions the trap can take by 1. When the number of actions is reduced to 0, the fountain is disabled.
Acid Spray Fountain.reset: The trap deactivates after 1 minute, at which point its acid reservoir is empty. It can't reactivate until this reservoir is refilled.
Acid Spray Fountain.routine: (3 actions) On its initiative, the trap makes an acid spray Strike against a random creature in the room for each of its actions.

action->Fountain Activation.name: Fountain Activation
action->Fountain Activation.description:
Trigger A creature steps on a pressure pad.

Effect The trap makes an acid spray Strike against a random creature in the room, although the initial damage is reduced by 8 as the acid eats through the concealing boxes. The trap then rolls initiative.

strike-melee->Acid Spray.name: Acid Spray
strike-melee->Acid Spray.description: No MAP applies to strikes made by acid spray attacks

action->No MAP.name: No MAP
action->No MAP.description: The Acid Spray Strikes do not apply a MAP.

action->Adolescent Sea Serpent Algae.name: Adolescent Sea Serpent Algae
action->Adolescent Sea Serpent Algae.description:
The water in the ballast organs around the sea serpent's neck is full of psychotropic algae.

Saving throw @Check[fortitude|dc:20|name:Adolescent Sea Serpent Algae Poison]

Maximum duration 3 rounds

Stage 1 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} and, if flying, spends its first action each turn to descend 20 feet (1 round)

action->Spine Rake.name: Spine Rake
action->Spine Rake.description: The young sea serpent extends the spines along its back and Swims or Strides. Each creature the serpent is adjacent to at any point during its movement takes @Damage[(1d8+4)[slashing]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:17|basic] save).

Aeon Nexus (3-4).name: Aeon Nexus (3-4)
Aeon Nexus (3-4).descriptionHazard: A small cluster of aeon stones floats two feet off the ground, orbiting by shards of shattered aeon stones that crackle with electricity.
Aeon Nexus (3-4).disable: @Check[thievery|dc:23|name:Remove Aeon Stone|traits:magical,trap] (trained) to remove one nexus aeon stone from the center
Aeon Nexus (3-4).routine: (3 actions) The trap loses one action each turn for each nexus aeon stone removed from its center. On each action, it shoots a jet of electrified, razor-sharp aeon stone shards at a different creature within 30 feet, dealing @Damage[1d8[piercing]] damage and @Damage[1d8[electricity]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:21|basic|name:Aeon Nexus]).
Aeon Nexus (3-4).stealth: (DC 20 to find the cluster of aeon stones at the center of the nexus in the fog)

action->Static.name: Static
action->Static.description:
Trigger A creature who is not carrying a wayfinder with an aeon stone from the nexus slotted into it approaches within 15 feet of the aeon nexus

Effect The trap shocks the target, dealing @Damage[2d8[electricity]] damage to the triggering creature (@Check[reflex|dc:21|basic]), then rolls initiative.

Aeon Nexus (5-6).name: Aeon Nexus (5-6)
Aeon Nexus (5-6).descriptionHazard: A small cluster of aeon stones floats two feet off the ground, orbiting by shards of shattered aeon stones that crackle with electricity.

On each action, it shoots a jet of electrified, razor-sharp aeon stone shards at a different creature within 30 feet, dealing @Damage[(1d8+3)[piercing]] damage and @Damage[(1d8+3)[electricity]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:23|basic|name:Aeon Nexus]).
Aeon Nexus (5-6).stealth: (DC 23 to find the cluster of aeon stones at the center of the nexus in the fog)

action->Static.name: Static
action->Static.description:

action->Coven.description:
Ahksiva adds @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.J6vNvrUT3b1hx2iA]{Entangling Flora}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.KSAEhNfZyXMO7Z7V]{Outcast's Curse}, and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.KsWhliKfUs3IpW3c]{Wall of Thorns} to her coven's spells.

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->Sound Imitation.name: Sound Imitation
action->Sound Imitation.description: A green hag who succeeds at a Deception check to Lie can mimic the sounds of any animal found near her lair. She has a +4 circumstance bonus to this check.

action->Betraying Touch.name: Betraying Touch
action->Betraying Touch.description: Ahksiva touches a creature that doesn't realize she is an enemy. The betrayed creature is affected by her enfeebling humors and takes a -4 circumstance penalty to their saving throw against that effect.

action->Change Shape.name: Change Shape
action->Change Shape.description: Ahksiva can take on the appearance of any Medium humanoid woman. This doesn't change her Speed or her attack and damage bonuses with her Strikes, but might change the damage type her Strikes deal (typically to bludgeoning).

action->Enfeebling Humors.name: Enfeebling Humors
action->Enfeebling Humors.description: A creature damaged by a hag's claw must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:19] save or be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} for 1 day. On a critical failure, or if it gets hit again and fails its save a second time, it's @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} for 1 day.

action->Exhale Miasma.name: Exhale Miasma
action->Exhale Miasma.description: Ahksiva exhales a miasma of green vapors. Each living creature in a @Template[cone|distance:15] is affected by her enfeebling humors (attempting a save as normal). She can't use Exhale Miasma again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Exhale Miasma]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Tail Lash.name: Tail Lash
action->Tail Lash.description:
Trigger A creature within reach of Ahrkinos's tail uses an action to Strike or attempt a skill check.

Effect Ahrkinos attempts to Strike the triggering creature with his tail. If he hits, the creature takes a -2 circumstance penalty to the triggering roll.

action->Caustic Mucus.name: Caustic Mucus
action->Caustic Mucus.description:
Ahrkinos spits a ball of caustic mucus up to a range of 50 feet that explodes in a @Template[burst|distance:10]. Creatures within the burst take @Damage[5d6[acid]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:20|basic] save). Those that fail this save also take @Damage[1d6[persistent,acid]] damage and take a -5-foot status penalty to their Speed. This Speed reduction ends with the persistent acid damage.

Ahrkinos can't use Caustic Mucus again for [[/gmr 1d6 #Recharge Caustic Mucus]]{1d6 rounds}.

action->Draconic Frenzy.name: Draconic Frenzy
action->Draconic Frenzy.description: Ahrkinos makes one fangs Strike and two tail Strikes in any order.

action->Old Bones.name: Old Bones
action->Old Bones.description: Ahrkinos's age has left him infirm and makes it difficult for him to fly. Ahrkinos becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.HL2l2VRSaQHu9lUw]{Fatigued} if he uses more than one Fly action to fly in a single round. His Speed Surge is considered one Fly action for this purpose. In addition, he immediately begins to fall at the end of his turn if he is flying, but treats the fall as 40 feet shorter.

action->Speed Surge.name: Speed Surge
action->Speed Surge.description: Ahrkinos moves up to twice his Speed. He can do this three times per day.

action->Pounce.name: Pounce
action->Pounce.description: The fox Strides and makes a Strike at the end of that movement. If the fox begins this action hidden, it remains hidden until after this ability's Strike.

action->Support.name: Support
action->Support.description: The animal companion supports its druid master, tearing tendons with each opening. Until the start of the druid's next turn, any Strikes that damage targets that the animal companion threatens give the target a -5-foot status penalty to its Speeds for 1 minute (-10 on a critical success). While using Support, the only other actions an animal companion can use on its turn are movement actions to get into position. If an animal companion has used any other actions on its turn, it cannot Support its master.

If an Animal Companion has used any other actions on its turn, it cannot Support its master.

Ankle Trap (1-2).name: Ankle Trap (1-2)
Ankle Trap (1-2).descriptionHazard: Many small pits have been dug in the road and covered with leaves and dirt to disguise them.
Ankle Trap (1-2).disable: If spotted, the pits can be avoided by moving at one quarter of normal speed.

action->Trip Up.name: Trip Up
action->Trip Up.description:
Trigger A creature walks into the affected area

Effect Any creature that walks through the affected area must attempt a @Check[acrobatics|dc:14|name:Ankle Trap|traits:damaging-effect,hazard,mechanical,trap] check. Creatures that fail this check take @Damage[1d4[bludgeoning]] damage and a -5-foot penalty to their Speed for 1 hour. A critical failure increases the damage to @Damage[2d4[bludgeoning]] damage and reduces the creature's Speed by half for 1 hour.

Annis Hag (1-06).name: Annis Hag (1-06)
Annis Hag (1-06).publicNotes:
Annis hags are brutal torturers and murderers, delighting in the musical screams and tasty flesh of young creatures and those who are pure of heart. Annis hags are the most direct of all hags, engaging in physical combat and using their change shape ability to hunt rather than to infiltrate and betray humanoids. But an Annis hag takes a grisly trophy from each kill and uses it to sow discord, sending the trophy to one of her victim's loved ones in a way that implicates another family member in the murder. Also known as iron hags, annis hags have iron-like yet flexible flesh that resists edged weapons, and their own touch is the same cold iron that burns the flesh of other hags. This allows them to bully their way to the leadership of hag covens.

Malevolent crones who lurk at the edges of civilization, hags use their deceptive, magical abilities to prey upon humanoids, manipulating and corrupting them. Some say hags arose from fey that became twisted by their inner selfishness. Hags gather together in covens for greater power, craft unique magical items known as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.ACa9QlFqdmW4s2Th]{Hag Eyes}, and are known to replace infant humanoids with their own offspring-these children are@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-monster-core.Actor.RqX0vfUjlycKjGyp]{Changelings} who have the potential to become hags themselves.
Annis Hag (1-06).allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

action->Coven.name: Coven
action->Coven.description:
An annis hag adds @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.gPvtmKMRpg9I9D7H]{Earthbind}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.115Xp9E38CJENhNS]{Magic Passage}, and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.8Umt1AzYfFbC4fui]{Spellwrack} to her coven's spells.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.Coven]

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->Bonds of Iron.name: Bonds of Iron
action->Bonds of Iron.description:
Once per day, an annis hag can cause a cage built of cold iron fingernails to spring out of nothingness at a range of up to 30 feet, attempting an @Check[athletics|traits:action:grapple|overrideTraits:true] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.PMbdMWc2QroouFGD]{Grapple} against the target's Fortitude DC; if the target has a weakness to cold iron, the annis hag gains a +2 circumstance bonus to this check.

Unlike a normal Grapple, the annis hag doesn't need to be within reach and can move as she pleases, and a successful attempt lasts until the creature escapes (DC 24), causing the cage to crumble into rust.

Any creature can attempt to destroy the cage by attacking it. It has an AC of 19, Hardness 10, and 40 Hit Points.

action->Change Shape.name: Change Shape
action->Change Shape.description:
The hag can take on the appearance of any Medium female humanoid. This doesn't change her Speed or her attack and damage bonuses with her Strikes but might change the damage type her Strikes deal (typically to bludgeoning).

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.ChangeShape]

weapon->Hand Crossbow.name: Hand Crossbow
weapon->Hand Crossbow.description: Sometimes referred to as an alley bow by rogues or ruffians, this small crossbow fires small bolts that are sometimes used to deliver poison to the target. It's small enough to be shot one-handed, but it still requires two hands to load.

weapon->Scimitar.name: Scimitar
weapon->Scimitar.description: This one-handed curved blade is sharp on one side.

consumable->Bolts.name: Bolts
consumable->Bolts.description: Shorter than traditional arrows but similar in construction, bolts are the ammunition used by crossbows.

action->Single Out.name: Single Out
action->Single Out.description: The bandit designates one target it can see at a time. Against that target its multiple attack penalty becomes -3 (-2 with an agile weapon) and -6 (-4 with an agile weapon) for 1 minute

weapon->Alchemist's Fire (Lesser).name: Alchemist's Fire (Lesser)
weapon->Alchemist's Fire (Lesser).description:
Activate A Strike

Alchemist's fire is a combination of volatile liquids that ignite when exposed to air. Alchemist's fire deals 1d8 fire damage, 1 persistent fire damage, and 1 fire splash damage.

action->Sneak Attack.name: Sneak Attack
action->Sneak Attack.description: The bandit deals an extra 1d6 precision damage to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures.

action->Attach.name: Attach
action->Attach.description:
When a barbed bloodseeker hits a target larger than itself, its barbed legs attach it to that creature. This is similar to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbing} the creature, but the bloodseeker moves with that creature rather than holding it in place.

The bloodseeker is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} while attached. If the bloodseeker is killed or pushed away while attached to a creature it has drained blood from, that creature takes @Damage[1[bleed]] damage. Escaping the attach or removing the bloodseeker in other ways doesn't cause bleed damage.

action->Blood Drain.name: Blood Drain
action->Blood Drain.description:
Requirements The bloodseeker is attached to a creature.

Effect The bloodseeker uses its proboscis to drain blood from the creature it's attached to. This deals [[/r 1d6]]{1d6 damage}, and the bloodseeker gains temporary Hit Points equal to the damage dealt. A creature that has its blood drained by a bloodseeker is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} until it receives healing (of any kind or amount).

equipment->Spellbook.name: Spellbook
equipment->Spellbook.description: A spellbook holds the written knowledge necessary to learn and prepare various spells, a necessity for wizards (who typically get one for free) and a useful luxury for other spellcasters looking to learn additional spells. Each spellbook can hold up to 100 spells. The Price listed is for a blank spellbook.

action->Counterspell.name: Counterspell
action->Counterspell.description:
Trigger A creature Casts a Spell Barralbus has prepared.

Effect Barralbus expends a prepared spell to counter the triggering creature's casting of the same spell. He loses the spell slot as if he had cast the triggering spell. He then attempts to counteract the triggering spell.

equipment->Spellbook.name: Spellbook
equipment->Spellbook.description: A spellbook holds the written knowledge necessary to learn and prepare various spells, a necessity for wizards (who typically get one for free) and a useful luxury for other spellcasters looking to learn additional spells. Each spellbook can hold up to 100 spells. The Price listed is for a blank spellbook.

action->Counterspell.name: Counterspell
action->Counterspell.description:
Trigger A creature Casts a Spell Barralbus has prepared.

Effect Barralbus expends a prepared spell to counter the triggering creature's casting of the same spell. He loses the spell slot as if he had cast the triggering spell. He then attempts to counteract the triggering spell.

Bijan And Zaynap Ohrlavi.name: Bijan And Zaynap Ohrlavi
Bijan And Zaynap Ohrlavi.allSavesBonus: +1 status on all saves vs. poison

weapon->Acid Flask (Moderate) (Infused).name: Acid Flask (Moderate) (Infused)
weapon->Acid Flask (Moderate) (Infused).description:
Activate A Strike

This flask filled with corrosive acid deals 1 acid damage, 2d6 persistent acid damage, and 2 acid splash damage. You gain a +1 item bonus to attack rolls.

weapon->Bottled Lightning (Moderate) (In.name: Bottled Lightning (Moderate) (Infused)
weapon->Bottled Lightning (Moderate) (In.description:
Activate A Strike

Bottled lightning is packed with volatile reagents that create a blast of electricity when they are exposed to air. Bottled lightning deals 2d6 electricity damage and 2 electricity splash damage. On a hit, the target becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the start of your next turn. You gain a +1 item bonus to attack rolls.

weapon->Frost Vial (Moderate) (Infused).name: Frost Vial (Moderate) (Infused)
weapon->Frost Vial (Moderate) (Infused).description:
Activate 1 Strike

The liquid reagents in this vial rapidly absorb heat when exposed to air. A frost vial deals the listed cold damage and cold splash damage. On a hit, the target takes a status penalty to its Speeds until the end of its next turn. Many types of frost vial also grant an item bonus to attack rolls.

You gain a +1 item bonus to attack rolls, the bomb deals 2d6 cold damage and 2 cold splash damage, and the target takes a -10-foot penalty.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-effects.Item.LdmzgBOTjCete4F7]{Effect: Frost Vial}

equipment->Alchemist's Tools.name: Alchemist's Tools
equipment->Alchemist's Tools.description: This mobile collection of vials and chemicals can be used for simple alchemical tasks.

action->Infused Items.name: Infused Items
action->Infused Items.description: Each alchemist carries 2 infused moderate acid flasks, 2 infused moderate bottled lightnings, and 2 infused moderate frost vials. These items last for 24 hours or until the next time the alchemists make their daily preparations.

action->Alchemist Goggles.name: Alchemist Goggles
action->Alchemist Goggles.description: The alchemist's @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.7JVgLiNTAs4clEW8]{Alchemist Goggles} allow them to ignore lesser cover when making Strikes with alchemical bombs.

action->Calculated Bomber.name: Calculated Bomber
action->Calculated Bomber.description: The alchemist deals 5 splash damage with thrown alchemical bombs rather than the normal amount.

action->Quick Bomber.name: Quick Bomber
action->Quick Bomber.description: The alchemist draws an alchemical bomb with an Interact action and throws it as a ranged Strike.

action->Sneak Attack.name: Sneak Attack
action->Sneak Attack.description: If the alchemist's Strike hits an @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creature, they deal 1d6 extra precision damage.

Biloko Veteran (1-16).name: Biloko Veteran (1-16)
Biloko Veteran (1-16).publicNotes:
A biloko who has led a sufficient number of successful hunts garners the respect (and fear) of their companions.

Bilokos are crocodile-snouted fey who stalk the Mwangi Jungle and feast upon the flesh of humanoids. As cunning as they are vicious, bilokos employ deadly traps and guerrilla hunting tactics to capture prey-typically hapless explorers or, occasionally, wayward villagers, many of whom believe bilokos to be cruel ancestral spirits. The most powerful of these creatures, known as elokos, wield potent transformative magic.

Bilokos have a fondness for bells, and the sound of ringing bells often indicates their presence. In addition to carrying and ringing them while out hunting, bilokos sometimes enchant bells with potent magic, or hang them on strings to serve as alarms for their encampments.

Bilokos look like slender but wiry humanoids with crocodile-like heads, rust-colored skin, and blood-red eyes. They eat only the meat of humanoids, though they can survive for extended periods of time on a single meal thanks to their snakelike ability to consume a Medium humanoid creature whole. They do this by unhinging their jaws and slowly swallowing the victim from head to foot. Thanks to their acidic saliva and sharp teeth, a biloko can masticate their food into an easy-to-digest pulp, grinding flesh and bone into a compact mush, even while swallowing; thus, they do not flinch while devouring meals two or three times their own size.

A recently-fed biloko can be easily recognized by their sagging, distended belly. However, despite their slow appearance, the fey is no less dangerous then, as they delight in killing and might have hungry comrades hiding nearby, waiting to feed.

weapon->Longspear.name: Longspear
weapon->Longspear.description: This very long spear, sometimes called a pike, is purely for thrusting rather than throwing. Used by many soldiers and city watch for crowd control and defense against charging enemies, it must be wielded with two hands.

weapon->Shortbow.name: Shortbow
weapon->Shortbow.description: This smaller bow is made of a single piece of wood and favored by skirmishers and cavalry.

consumable->Arrows.name: Arrows
consumable->Arrows.description: These projectiles are the ammunition for bows. The shaft of an arrow is made of wood. It is stabilized in flight by fletching at one end and bears a metal head on the other.

action->Inspired Feast.name: Inspired Feast
action->Inspired Feast.description:
If a biloko feasts on a human corpse for 1 minute or more, they gain a +1 status bonus to attack rolls and a +2 status bonus to damage rolls for 1 hour.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.EM0VP31B8CyjFD15]{Effect: Inspired Feast}

action->Swipe.name: Swipe
action->Swipe.description:
The veteran makes a melee Strike and compares the attack roll result to the AC of up to two foes, each of whom must be within their melee reach and adjacent to each other. Roll damage only once and apply it to each creature hit.

A Swipe counts as two attacks for the veteran's multiple attack penalty.

Biloko Warrior (1-16).name: Biloko Warrior (1-16)
Biloko Warrior (1-16).publicNotes:
Bilokos prefer to move in small, stealthy packs through dark, isolated sections of the forest. When a band of bilokos finds a suitable hunting ground, they claim the area exclusively, digging pit traps, crafting snares from vines, and building blinds high in trees where they can lie in ambush.

Bilokos are crocodile-snouted fey who stalk the Mwangi Jungle and feast upon the flesh of humanoids. As cunning as they are vicious, bilokos employ deadly traps and guerrilla hunting tactics to capture prey-typically hapless explorers or, occasionally, wayward villagers, many of whom believe bilokos to be cruel ancestral spirits. They do this by unhinging their jaws and slowly swallowing the victim from head to foot. Thanks to their acidic saliva and sharp teeth, a biloko can masticate their food into an easy-to-digest pulp, grinding flesh and bone into a compact mush, even while swallowing; thus, they do not flinch while devouring meals two or three times their own size.

A recently-fed biloko can be easily recognized by their sagging, distended belly. However, despite their slow appearance, the fey is no less dangerous then, as they delight in killing and might have hungry comrades hiding nearby, waiting to feed.

weapon->Spear.name: Spear
weapon->Spear.description: A long metal shaft ending with a metal spike, a spear can be used one-handed as a melee weapon and can be thrown.

shield->Wooden Shield.name: Wooden Shield
shield->Wooden Shield.description:
Though they come in a variety of shapes and sizes, the protection offered by wooden shields comes from the stoutness of their materials. While wooden shields are less expensive than steel shields, they break more easily.

Hardness HP BT
3 12 6

action->Inspired Feast.name: Inspired Feast
action->Inspired Feast.description:
If a biloko feasts on a human corpse for 1 minute or more, they gain a +1 status bonus to attack rolls and a +2 status bonus to damage rolls for 1 hour.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.EM0VP31B8CyjFD15]{Effect: Inspired Feast}

equipment->Manacles (Simple).name: Manacles (Simple)
equipment->Manacles (Simple).description: You can manacle someone who is willing or otherwise at your mercy as an exploration activity taking 10-30 seconds depending on the creature's size and how many manacles you apply. A two-legged creature with its legs bound takes a -15-foot circumstance penalty to its Speeds, and a two-handed creature with its wrists bound has to succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:5] any time it uses a manipulate action or else that action fails. This DC may be higher depending on how tightly the manacles constrain the hands. A creature bound to a stationary object is immobilized. For creatures with more or fewer limbs, the GM determines what effect manacles have, if any. Freeing a creature from simple manacles requires three successful @Check[thievery|dc:22|traits:action:pick-a-lock] checks.

action->Hunt Prey.name: Hunt Prey
action->Hunt Prey.description: The Blue Streak ambusher designates a single creature they can see and hear, or one they're Tracking, as their prey. The ambusher gains a +2 circumstance bonus to Perception checks to Seek the prey and to Survival checks to Track the prey. This effect lasts until the Blue Streak ambusher uses Hunt Prey again.

action->Precision Edge.name: Precision Edge
action->Precision Edge.description: The first time the Blue Streak ambusher hits their hunted prey in a round, they deal an additional 1d8 precision damage.

0.label: First Hit against Hunted Prey this round

action->Running Reload.name: Running Reload
action->Running Reload.description: The Blue Streak ambusher Strides, Steps, or Sneaks, and then Interacts to reload.

weapon->+1 Kukri.name: +1 Kukri
weapon->+1 Kukri.description: The blade of this foot-long knife curves inward and lacks a cross guard at the hilt.

action->Hazard Spotter.name: Hazard Spotter
action->Hazard Spotter.description: The ambusher automatically attempts a secret Perception check to notice a hazard when they are within 10 feet of the hazard.

action->Trick Attack.name: Trick Attack
action->Trick Attack.description: The ambusher musters their guile to attempt a clever attack that catches their foe unprepared. The ambusher chooses one of their weapons. The next attack with that weapon deals an extra 2d6 precision damage. In addition, the ambusher can Interact to draw the weapon (or to reload it if they choose the sniper rifle).

Blue Streak Burglar.name: Blue Streak Burglar
Blue Streak Burglar.allSavesBonus: +1 circumstance to all saves vs. traps

equipment->Thieves' Tools.name: Thieves' Tools
equipment->Thieves' Tools.description:
You need thieves' tools to Pick Locks or Disable Devices (of some types) using the Thievery skill.

If your thieves' tools are broken, you can repair them by replacing the lock picks with @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.Sw7MBLASN3xK4Y44]{Replacement Picks} appropriate to your tools; this doesn't require using the Repair action.

consumable->Darkvision Elixir (Lesser).name: Darkvision Elixir (Lesser)
consumable->Darkvision Elixir (Lesser).description:
Activate 1 Interact

After you drink this elixir, your sight becomes sharper in darkness. You gain darkvision for 10 minutes.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-effects.Item.7UL8belWmo7U5YGM]{Effect: Darkvision Elixir (Lesser)}

action->+1 Circumstance Bonus to All Sav.name: +1 Circumstance Bonus to All Saves and AC vs. Traps

action->Deny Advantage.name: Deny Advantage
action->Deny Advantage.description: The burglar isn't @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} to creatures of 4th level or lower that are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden}, undetected, flanking, or using surprise attack.

action->Nimble Dodge.name: Nimble Dodge
action->Nimble Dodge.description:
Trigger The burglar is targeted with a melee or ranged attack by an attacker they can see

Effect The burglar gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against the triggering attack.

action->Mobility.name: Mobility
action->Mobility.description: When the burglar Strides half their Speed or less, that movement does not trigger reactions.

action->Sneak Attack.name: Sneak Attack
action->Sneak Attack.description: The burglar deals an extra 1d6 precision damage to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures.

action->Surprise Attack.name: Surprise Attack
action->Surprise Attack.description: On the first round of combat, if the burglar rolls Deception or Stealth for initiative, creatures that haven't acted are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} to them.

equipment->Spellbook.name: Spellbook
equipment->Spellbook.description: A spellbook holds the written knowledge necessary to learn and prepare various spells, a necessity for wizards (who typically get one for free) and a useful luxury for other spellcasters looking to learn additional spells. Each spellbook can hold up to 100 spells. The Price listed is for a blank spellbook.

equipment->Thieves' Tools.name: Thieves' Tools
equipment->Thieves' Tools.description:
You need thieves' tools to Pick Locks or Disable Devices (of some types) using the Thievery skill.

If your thieves' tools are broken, you can repair them by replacing the lock picks with @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.Sw7MBLASN3xK4Y44]{Replacement Picks} appropriate to your tools; this doesn't require using the Repair action.

equipment->Spellbook.name: Spellbook
equipment->Spellbook.description: A spellbook holds the written knowledge necessary to learn and prepare various spells, a necessity for wizards (who typically get one for free) and a useful luxury for other spellcasters looking to learn additional spells. Each spellbook can hold up to 100 spells. The Price listed is for a blank spellbook.

consumable->Scroll of Spectral Hand (Lev.name: Scroll of Spectral Hand (Level 2)
consumable->Scroll of Spectral Hand (Lev.description:
@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.rthC6dGm3nNrt1xN]{Ghostly Carrier}

Casting a Spell from a scroll requires holding the scroll in one hand and activating it with a Cast a Spell activity using the normal number of actions for that spell.

To Cast a Spell from a scroll, the spell must appear on your spell list. Because you're the one Casting the Spell, use your spell attack roll and spell DC. The spell also gains the appropriate trait for your tradition (arcane, divine, occult, or primal).

Any physical material components and costs are provided when a scroll is created, so you don't need to provide them when Casting a Spell from a scroll. You must replace any required material component for that spell with a somatic component. If the spell requires a focus, you must have that focus to Cast the Spell from a scroll.

Note: To create a scroll or wand of a specific spell, drag the spell from the compendium or compendium browser into the inventory of a PC, NPC, or loot actor.

action->Stench of Decay.name: Stench of Decay
action->Stench of Decay.description: 5 feet. The Blue Streak mage emits a scent of putrid rot in a 5-foot emanation. A creature that enters or begins its turn in the aura is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}.

action->Drain Bonded Item.name: Drain Bonded Item
action->Drain Bonded Item.description:
Frequency once per day Requirements The Blue Streak mage hasn't taken an action yet on this turn

Effect The Blue Streak mage expends the power stored in their mace. This gives them the ability to cast one prepared spell they prepared today and already cast, without spending a spell slot.

action->Sentry's Aim.name: Sentry's Aim
action->Sentry's Aim.description: The Blue Streak sentry aims carefully and fires. They make a ranged weapon Strike with a +1 circumstance bonus. The Strike ignores the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition, lesser cover, and standard cover, and reduces greater cover to standard cover.

Boggard Pit (3-4).name: Boggard Pit (3-4)
Boggard Pit (3-4).descriptionHazard: A net with soil and aquatic plants on it covers a 10-foot pit dug into the bottom of a body of water.
Boggard Pit (3-4).disable: @Check[thievery|dc:15|name:Remove the Net|traits:mechanical,trap] to remove the net
Boggard Pit (3-4).reset: Others can fall into the pit, but the net entangles only the first creature to trigger the trap. The net must be reset manually.

action->Pitfall.name: Pitfall
action->Pitfall.description:
Trigger A creature walks on the net.

Effect The triggering creature falls into a spiked pit and submerges, with the net collapsing to entangle the creature. Spikes in the pit deal @Damage[2d6[piercing]] damage. The net imposes a -10-foot penalty to the creature's speed. A creature must succeed at two DC 15 checks to Escape from the net; a critical success to Escape frees them immediately. A creature that can't breathe underwater may begin drowning. Any round the creature struggles to escape the net, the creature uses 2 rounds of air.

Boggard Pit (5-6).name: Boggard Pit (5-6)
Boggard Pit (5-6).descriptionHazard: A net with soil and aquatic plants on it covers a 10-foot pit dug into the bottom of a body of water.
Boggard Pit (5-6).disable: @Check[thievery|dc:18|name:Remove the Net|traits:mechanical,trap] to remove the net
Boggard Pit (5-6).reset: Others can fall into the pit, but the net entangles only the first creature to trigger the trap. The net must be reset manually.

action->Pitfall.name: Pitfall
action->Pitfall.description:
Trigger A creature walks on the net.

Effect The triggering creature falls into a spiked pit and submerges, with the net collapsing to entangle the creature. Spikes in the pit deal @Damage[2d10[piercing]] damage. The net imposes a -10-foot penalty to the creature's speed. A creature must succeed at two DC 18 checks to Escape from the net a critical success to Escape frees them immediately. A creature that can't breathe underwater may begin drowning. Any round the creature struggles to escape the net, the creature uses 2 rounds of air.

Boggard Swampseer (PFS 1-24).name: Boggard Swampseer (PFS 1-24)
Boggard Swampseer (PFS 1-24).publicNotes:
The boggard swampseer has been gifted with magic through its worship of the demon lord Gogunta, and uses its power to rule a boggard village, keeping the rest of the village in line and planning raids on nearby communities.

Boggards are aggressive humanoid amphibians that thrive in swamps, marshes, and even some rain forests. Boggards hatch from eggs into tadpoles, fiercely competing for food and even consuming their siblings in that struggle. Over 3 years, the surviving boggards develops arms, legs, and lungs while learning the rudiments of hunting, crafts, and warfare-everything needed to survive in their might-makes-right society. At the top of most boggard hierarchies lords a hulking swampseer imbued with sinister divine magic.

action->Destructive Croak.name: Destructive Croak
action->Destructive Croak.description:
The swampseer utters a powerful croak that deals @Damage[4d6[sonic]] damage to any non-boggard within a @Template[emanation|distance:15] (@Check[fortitude|dc:19|basic] save).

Any creature with the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened} condition takes additional sonic damage equal to twice the value of their frightened condition.

The boggard can't use Destructive Croak again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Destructive Croak]]{1d4 rounds}

action->Drowning Drone.name: Drowning Drone
action->Drowning Drone.description:
Trigger The boggard swampseer or one of its allies within 60 feet attempts a saving throw against an auditory or sonic effect.

Effect The swampseer releases a croak that drowns out other sound. It rolls a @Check[performance] check. It and boggard allies in the area can use the higher result of the swampseer's Performance check or their saves to resolve the effects against the auditory or sonic effect.

action->Swamp Stride.name: Swamp Stride
action->Swamp Stride.description: A boggard swampseer ignores difficult terrain caused by swamp terrain features.

action->Terrifying Croak.name: Terrifying Croak
action->Terrifying Croak.description:
The boggard swampseer unleashes a terrifying croak. Any non-boggard within @Template[emanation|distance:30] becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1} unless they succeed at a @Check[will|dc:19] save.

Those who critically succeed are temporarily immune for 1 minute.

action->Tongue Grab.name: Tongue Grab
action->Tongue Grab.description:
If the boggard swampseer hits a creature with its tongue, that creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} by the boggard. Unlike with a normal grab, the creature isn't @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized}, but it can't move beyond the reach of the boggard's tongue.

A creature can sever the tongue by hitting AC 15 and dealing at least 4 slashing damage. Though this doesn't deal any damage to the boggard, it prevents it from using its tongue Strike until it regrows its tongue, which takes a week.

Boggard Warrior (PFS 1-09).name: Boggard Warrior (PFS 1-09)
Boggard Warrior (PFS 1-09).publicNotes:
Boggard warriors exalt in single combat, and prefer to fight alone so that none can contest their kills. They have been known to pursue enemies who flee combat with a single-mindedness that seems almost supernatural.

Boggards are aggressive humanoid amphibians that thrive in swamps, marshes, and even some rain forests. Boggards hatch from eggs into tadpoles, fiercely competing for food and even consuming their siblings in that struggle. Over 3 years, the surviving boggards develops arms, legs, and lungs while learning the rudiments of hunting, crafts, and warfare-everything needed to survive in their might-makes-right society. At the top of most boggard hierarchies lords a hulking swampseer imbued with sinister divine magic.

weapon->Club.name: Club
weapon->Club.description: This is a piece of stout wood shaped or repurposed to bludgeon an enemy. Clubs can be intricately carved pieces of martial art or as simple as a tree branch or piece of wood.

weapon->Javelin.name: Javelin
weapon->Javelin.description: This thin spear is well balanced for throwing but is not designed for melee use.

armor->Studded Leather Armor.name: Studded Leather Armor
armor->Studded Leather Armor.description: This leather armor is reinforced with metal studs and sometimes small metal plates, providing most of the flexibility of leather armor with more robust protection.

action->Swamp Stride.name: Swamp Stride
action->Swamp Stride.description: A boggard warrior ignores difficult terrain caused by swamp terrain features.

action->Terrifying Croak.name: Terrifying Croak
action->Terrifying Croak.description:
The boggard warrior unleashes a terrifying croak. Any non-boggard within @Template[emanation|distance:30]{30 feet} becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1} unless they succeed at a @Check[will|dc:18] save.

Those who critically succeed are temporarily immune for 1 minute.

action->Tongue Grab.name: Tongue Grab
action->Tongue Grab.description:
If the boggard warrior hits a creature with its tongue, that creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} by the boggard. Unlike with a normal grab, the creature isn't @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized}, but it can't move beyond the reach of the boggard's tongue.

A creature can sever the tongue by hitting AC 15 and dealing at least 3 slashing damage. Though this doesn't deal any damage to the boggard, it prevents it from using its tongue Strike until it regrows its tongue, which takes a week.

action->Final Spite.name: Final Spite
action->Final Spite.description:
Trigger The wight is reduced to 0 Hit Points.

Effect The wight makes a Strike before being destroyed. It doesn't gain any temporary HP from drain life on this Strike.

action->Drain Life.name: Drain Life
action->Drain Life.description: When the wight damages a living creature with its claw Strike, the wight gains 3 temporary Hit Points and the creature must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:17] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}. Further damage dealt by the wraith increases the amount of drain by 1 on a failed save to a maximum of drained 4.

action->Wight Spawn.name: Wight Spawn
action->Wight Spawn.description:
A living humanoid slain by a wight's claw Strike rises as a wight after [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}.

This wight spawn is under the command of the wight that killed it. It doesn't have Drain Life or and becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} for as long as it is a wight spawn. If the creator of the wight spawn dies, the wight spawn becomes a full-fledged, autonomous wight; it regains its free will, gains Drain Life and Wight Spawn, and is no longer clumsy.

equipment->Lute.name: Lute
equipment->Lute.description: Handheld instruments include bagpipes, a small set of chimes, small drums, fiddles and viols, flutes and recorders, small harps, lutes, trumpets, and similarly sized instruments. The GM might rule that an especially large handheld instrument (like a tuba) has greater Bulk. Heavy instruments such as large drums, a full set of chimes, and keyboard instruments are less portable and generally need to be stationary while played.

equipment->Thieves' Tools.name: Thieves' Tools
equipment->Thieves' Tools.description:
You need thieves' tools to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.2EE4aF4SZpYf0R6H]{Pick Locks} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6]{Disable Devices} (of some types) using the Thievery skill.

If your thieves' tools are broken, you can repair them by replacing the lock picks with @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.Sw7MBLASN3xK4Y44]{Replacement Picks} appropriate to your tools; this doesn't require using the Repair action. If you wear your thieves' tools, you can draw and replace them as part of the action that uses them.

action->Versatile Performance.name: Versatile Performance
action->Versatile Performance.description: The charlatan can use Performance instead of Diplomacy to Make an Impression and instead of Intimidation to Demoralize. They can also use an acting Performance instead of Deception to Impersonate.

action->Sneak Attack.name: Sneak Attack
action->Sneak Attack.description: The charlatan deals an extra 1d6 precision damage to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures.

action->Brutish Shove.name: Brutish Shove
action->Brutish Shove.description:
Chops makes a single Strike with a two-handed melee weapon. If he hits a target that is their size or smaller, that creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the end of the brute's turn, and he can automatically @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.action-macros.Macro.yNry1xMZqdWHncbV]{Shove: Athletics} it with the same benefits as the Shove action (including the critical success effect, if the Strike was a critical hit). If Chops moves to follow the target, that movement doesn't trigger reactions. This Strike has the following failure effect.

Failure The target becomes off-guard until the end of Chops's current turn.

action->Pack Attack.name: Pack Attack
action->Pack Attack.description: The cinder wolf's Strikes deal 1d4 extra precision damage to creatures within reach of at least two of the wolf's allies.

action->Smoke Vision.name: Smoke Vision
action->Smoke Vision.description: The cinder wolf ignores the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition from smoke.

action->Pack Attack.name: Pack Attack
action->Pack Attack.description: The cinder wolf's Strikes deal 1d4 extra damage to creatures within reach of at least two of the wolf's allies.

Collapsing Barricade (1-2).name: Collapsing Barricade (1-2)
Collapsing Barricade (1-2).descriptionHazard: A tunnel through this steep barricade is rigged to collapse. If a kobold spends one action to throw a lever, the tunnel collapses on the next creature to pass through.
Collapsing Barricade (1-2).disable: @Check[thievery|dc:18] (trained) to carefully trigger the collapse without entering the tunnel or @Check[thievery|dc:22] (trained) to brace the tunnel so it is safe to pass through.

action->Collapse.name: Collapse
action->Collapse.description:
Trigger A creature crawls into the tunnel in the collapsing barricade after the trap is activated with the lever

Effect The barricade collapses on the creature, who must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:22|traits:damaging-effect] save.

Critical Success The creature takes no damage and escapes the barricade, emerging into a safe space on either side of it.

Success The creature takes @Damage[(1d6+2)[bludgeoning]] damage from collapsing debris and @Damage[(1d6+2)[slashing]] damage from broken glass before emerging on the opposite side of the barricade from the one they entered.

Failure The creature takes @Damage[(2d6+4)[bludgeoning]] damage from collapsing debris and @Damage[(2d6+4)[slashing]] damage from broken glass before emerging on the opposite side of the barricade from the one they entered.

Critical Failure As a failure, and the creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} beneath the barricade until they or another creature succeed at a @Check[athletics|dc:22|name:Escape Barricade] check to pull them free. They can still be targeted, touched, and otherwise interacted with by creatures on either side of the barrier.

Collapsing Barricade (3-4).name: Collapsing Barricade (3-4)
Collapsing Barricade (3-4).descriptionHazard: A tunnel through this steep barricade is rigged to collapse. If a kobold spends one action to throw a lever, the tunnel collapses on the next creature to pass through.
Collapsing Barricade (3-4).disable: @Check[thievery|dc:25] (trained) to carefully trigger the collapse without entering the tunnel.

action->Collapse.name: Collapse
action->Collapse.description:
Trigger A creature crawls into the tunnel in the collapsing barricade after the trap is activated with the lever

Effect The barricade collapses on the creature, who must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:25|traits:damaging-effect] save.

Critical Success The creature takes no damage and escapes the barricade, emerging into a safe space on either side of it.

Success The creature takes @Damage[(1d8+3)[bludgeoning]] damage from collapsing debris and @Damage[(1d8+3)[slashing]] damage from broken glass before emerging on the opposite side of the barricade from the one they entered.

Failure The creature takes @Damage[(2d8+7)[bludgeoning]] damage from collapsing debris and @Damage[(2d8+7)[slashing]] damage from broken glass before emerging on the opposite side of the barricade from the one they entered.

Critical Failure As a failure, and the creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} beneath the barricade until they or another creature succeed at a @Check[athletics|dc:22|name:Escape Barricade] check to pull them free. They can still be targeted, touched, and otherwise interacted with by creatures on either side of the barrier.

Collapsing Ceiling (1-2).name: Collapsing Ceiling (1-2)
Collapsing Ceiling (1-2).descriptionHazard: The damaged ceiling is the only thing stopping the centipedes lairing above from falling through.
Collapsing Ceiling (1-2).disable: @Check[crafting|dc:19] (trained) to reinforce the ceiling with boards from the broken door.

action->Collapse.name: Collapse
action->Collapse.description:
Trigger A creature walks into the area beneath the centipede lair.

Effect Hearing potential prey, the centipedes begin scrabbling above, causing the ceiling to collapse and centipedes to rain down, dealing @Damage[(2d6+3)[bludgeoning]] damage to each creature in the area; each creature in the area must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:16|traits:damaging-effect] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes half damage.

Failure The creature takes full damage.

Critical Failure The creature takes double damage and is knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

Collapsing Ceiling (3-4).name: Collapsing Ceiling (3-4)
Collapsing Ceiling (3-4).descriptionHazard: The damaged ceiling is the only thing stopping the centipedes lairing above from falling through.
Collapsing Ceiling (3-4).disable: @Check[crafting|dc:22] (trained) to reinforce the ceiling with boards from the broken door.

action->Collapse.name: Collapse
action->Collapse.description:
Trigger A creature walks into the area beneath the centipede lair.

Effect Hearing potential prey, the centipedes begin scrabbling above, causing the ceiling to collapse and centipedes to rain down, dealing @Damage[(3d8+4)[bludgeoning]] damage to each creature in the area; each creature in the area must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:19|traits:damaging-effect] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes half damage.

Failure The creature takes full damage.

Critical Failure The creature takes double damage and is knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

Collapsing Floor.name: Collapsing Floor
Collapsing Floor.descriptionHazard: Around the edges of the pit, more rotting boards are ready to give way.
Collapsing Floor.reset: As the damage to the floor spreads, the areas adjacent to the new pit become new areas of this hazard.

action->Pitfall.name: Pitfall
action->Pitfall.description:
Trigger A creature walks next to the pit.

Effect The triggering creature falls in and takes falling damage (typically @Damage[3[bludgeoning]|options:fall-damage] damage) plus @Damage[4d6[piercing]] damage from landing on broken boards.

That creature can attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.3yoajuKjwHZ9ApUY]{Grab an Edge} to avoid falling; the DC to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climb} the walls or Grab an Edge is 18.

Creeping Slime.name: Creeping Slime
Creeping Slime.descriptionHazard: The thick green slime has been imbued with foul hag magic, making it cling to and grow over living creatures that touch it.
Creeping Slime.disable: @Check[thievery|dc:17] (trained) to carefully push the slime away without causing it to grow, @Check[crafting|dc:17] (one action) to neutralize it with alchemical reagents, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (2nd level; counteract DC 15 [DC 18 in Subtier 3-4]) to counteract the magic animating it. Casting a 1st-rank or higher spell with the water trait washes away the slime.

action->Coat with Slime.name: Coat with Slime
action->Coat with Slime.description:
Trigger A creature steps into the slime covering the steps and upper landing.

Effect The slime rapidly climbs across the creature's body, grows cold, and congeals. Creatures assaulted by the slime take @Damage[(1d8+5)[cold]] damage(@Check[fortitude|dc:17|basic] save); creatures that fail their save are also coated in slime, imposing a -5 foot circumstance penalty to their Speeds. The slime can't be easily cleaned away, and it requires ten minutes of bathing with clean water and soap to remove the slime.

weapon->Dagger.name: Dagger
weapon->Dagger.description: This small, bladed weapon is held in one hand and used to stab a creature in close combat. It can also be thrown.

armor->Studded Leather Armor.name: Studded Leather Armor
armor->Studded Leather Armor.description: This leather armor is reinforced with metal studs and sometimes small metal plates, providing most of the flexibility of leather armor with more robust protection.

action->Crowd Aid.name: Crowd Aid
action->Crowd Aid.description: The crowd agitator ignores difficult terrain caused by friendly crowds. Creatures within or adjacent to friendly crowds are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} against the crowd agitator's attacks.

action->Crowd Aid.name: Crowd Aid
action->Crowd Aid.description:
The crowd leader ignores difficult terrain caused by friendly crowds.

Creatures within or adjacent to friendly crowds are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} against the crowd leader's attacks.

Crowd with Chamberpots.name: Crowd with Chamberpots
Crowd with Chamberpots.descriptionHazard: The crowd is riled up enough to start throwing chamberpots at the interlopers, but not riled up enough to risk their lives. The crowd fills nine contiguous squares but can be shaped to fit the streets. Characters can move through the crowd, but spaces occupied by the crowd are difficult terrain.
Crowd with Chamberpots.disable: After more people in the crowd have become shaken or taken damage than there are crowd leaders left standing, the crowd disperses. For abilities affecting an area, count each affected square as one member of the crowd.
Crowd with Chamberpots.reset: After more people in the crowd have become shaken or taken damage than there are crowd leaders left standing, the crowd disperses. For abilities affecting an area, count each affected square as one member of the crowd.
Crowd with Chamberpots.routine: (3 actions) The crowd uses its first action to Stride away from any opponent adjacent to them (or to get within 30 feet), then uses each remaining action to make a chamber pot Strike at a different target.

Crowd with Trash.name: Crowd with Trash
Crowd with Trash.descriptionHazard: The crowd is riled up enough to start throwing garbage at the interlopers, but not riled up enough to risk their lives. The crowd fills nine contiguous squares but can be shaped to fit the streets. Characters can move through the crowd, but spaces occupied by the crowd are difficult terrain.
Crowd with Trash.disable: After more people in the crowd have become shaken or taken damage than there are crowd leaders left standing, the crowd disperses. For abilities affecting an area, count each affected square as one member of the crowd.
Crowd with Trash.reset: After more people in the crowd have become shaken or taken damage than there are crowd leaders left standing, the crowd disperses. For abilities affecting an area, count each affected square as one member of the crowd.
Crowd with Trash.routine: (3 actions) The crowd uses its first action to Stride away from any opponent adjacent to them (or to get within 30 feet), then uses each remaining action to make a trash Strike at a different target.

Crumbling Floor.name: Crumbling Floor
Crumbling Floor.descriptionHazard: Around the edges of the pit, more rotting boards are ready to give way.
Crumbling Floor.reset: As the damage to the floor spreads, the areas adjacent to the new pit become new areas of this hazard.

action->Pitfall.name: Pitfall
action->Pitfall.description:
Trigger A creature walks next to the pit.

Effect The triggering creature falls in and takes falling damage (typically @Damage[3[bludgeoning]|options:fall-damage] damage) plus @Damage[2d6[piercing]] damage from landing on broken boards.

That creature can attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.3yoajuKjwHZ9ApUY]{Grab an Edge} to avoid falling; the DC to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climb} the walls or Grab an Edge is 14.

Damaged Alchemical Golem.name: Damaged Alchemical Golem
Damaged Alchemical Golem.publicNotes:
This golem is a walking alchemical nightmare capable of inflicting all manner of painful wounds. Its ability to follow orders is granted by the otherwise mindless humanoid brain that floats in its dome-like head. In exceptionally rare cases, the brain used in its creation might retain fragments of memories or even actual intellect, resulting in an alchemical golem with a personality and agenda of its own.

Crafted of base materials and then magically animated into a powerful guardian, the legendary golem is a living construct that mindlessly obeys its creator's commands-often continuing to do so for years or even centuries after its creator's death. There exist two known methods of animating a golem. The traditional method involves harvesting and implanting an elemental soul or essence within the newly crafted host statue, a procedure seen as vile and blasphemous to those who value the sanctity of the soul; evil or amoral golem crafters tend to prefer this method. The other, less disreputable technique involves siphoning pure vitality energy into the statue to artificially imitate the creation of a soul. The result does not give the golem a true soul and is generally a more costly and time-consuming method of creation. Regardless of the method used, the resulting golem functions the same. A golem's unique animating force leaves it susceptible to certain forms of magic, but apart from these few weaknesses, it is impervious to magic and difficult to damage with weapons.

Golems work best in play as foes to vanquish rather than allies to accompany player characters on adventures. The process of creating a golem is time-consuming, expensive, and difficult, and only the most talented spellcasters or artisans can even hope to accomplish such an undertaking. While certain magical texts-so-called "golem manuals"-are said to aid golems crafters, for the most part the creation of a golem should be something left in the hands of the Game Master.

Golems have components that can be harvested as trophies or magical components; the value depends on the golem in question. Examples of components that can be harvested from golems are listed in the sidebars.

action->Alchemical Rupture.name: Alchemical Rupture
action->Alchemical Rupture.description:
When an alchemical golem takes physical damage from a critical hit or is affected by a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.1xbFBQDRs0hT5xZ9]{Shatter} spell, one glass chamber within its body shatters, spewing alchemical liquid in a @Template[emanation|distance:5].

Roll on the altered alchemical chambers list to determine which one shatters, and any creatures hit are affected as listed (@Check[reflex|dc:24]).

[[/gmr 1d6 #Alchemical Chambers]] Alchemical Effect
1-2 @Check[fortitude|dc:19] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} on a critical failure)
3-4 @Check[fortitude|dc:19] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} on a critical failure)
5-6 @Check[fortitude|dc:19] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed} for 1 round (slowed for 2 rounds on a critical failure)

action->Altered Alchemical Chambers.name: Altered Alchemical Chambers
action->Altered Alchemical Chambers.description:
The damaged alchemical golem's chemicals have changed after a long period of inactivity. When an alchemical golem ability calls upon a randomly determined alchemical effect, roll 1d6 and consult the following (if you roll the result of a chamber that was shattered, there is no alchemical effect):

[[/gmr 1d6 #Alchemical Chambers]] Alchemical Effect
1-2 @Check[fortitude|dc:19] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} on a critical failure)
3-4 @Check[fortitude|dc:19] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} on a critical failure)
5-6 @Check[fortitude|dc:19] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed} for 1 round (slowed for 2 rounds on a critical failure)

action->Golem Antimagic.name: Golem Antimagic
action->Golem Antimagic.description:
Harmed by sonic (@Damage[1d8[untyped]], @Damage[1d6[untyped]] from areas or persistent damage); slowed by cold

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.GolemAntimagic]

action->Alchemical Injection.name: Alchemical Injection
action->Alchemical Injection.description:
When an alchemical golem hits a creature with a syringe Strike, roll 1d6 on the alchemical chambers list to determine the additional effect of the attack.

The syringe exposes the creature to the effect rolled.

[[/gmr 1d6 #Alchemical Chambers]] Alchemical Effect
1-2 @Check[fortitude|dc:19] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} on a critical failure)
3-4 @Check[fortitude|dc:19] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} on a critical failure)
5-6 @Check[fortitude|dc:19] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed} for 1 round (slowed for 2 rounds on a critical failure)

Dead Organ (5-6).name: Dead Organ (5-6)
Dead Organ (5-6).descriptionHazard: A magical pipe organ for controlling and bolstering the undead. Creatures that are trained in Performance can spend one action to attempt to play a tune.
Dead Organ (5-6).disable: @Check[thievery|dc:25|name:Stopper the Pipes SC|traits:magical,necromancy] (expert) to stopper the pipes. Each pipe stoppered imparts a stacking -1 circumstance penalty to Performance checks with the organ. Once four pipes have been stoppered, the organ ceases to function.

action->Play a Tune.name: Play a Tune
action->Play a Tune.description:
Trigger An adjacent creature attempts to play the organ

Effect The performer makes a @Check[performance|dc:21|name:Play the Dead Organ|traits:magical,necromancy] check.

Critical Success As success, and all other creatures who attempt to perform on the dead organ suffer a -1 status penalty to Play a Tune for 1 round.

Success Creatures within 100 feet of the organ are subjected to one of the following effects, as chosen by the performer:

  • Bolster (auditory, necromancy): Mindless undead within range gain a +1 status bonus to attack and damage rolls for 1 round.
  • Dance (auditory, move, necromancy): Mindless undead within range Stride up to 15 feet in the same cardinal direction. All targets move the same distance. If impeded, they move as far as possible, then stop.
  • Discordant Blast (auditory, evocation, sonic): All living creatures within 10 feet of the organ except the performer suffer @Damage[(2d8+9)[sonic]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:24|basic|name:Discordant Blast|traits:auditory,evocation,magical,sonic,necromancy] save). On a failure or critical failure, a creature is also pushed 15 feet away from the organ.
  • Swing (attack, auditory, flourish, necromancy): Mindless undead within range make a Strike in the same relative cardinal direction. This Strike doesn't count toward the undead creatures' multiple attack penalty, and their multiple attack penalty doesn't apply to this Strike.
  • Weaken (auditory, necromancy): Mindless undead within range suffer a -1 status penalty to attack and damage rolls for 1 round.

Critical Failure The player alone experiences the effects of a discordant blast.

Dead Organ (7-8).name: Dead Organ (7-8)
Dead Organ (7-8).descriptionHazard: A magical pipe organ for controlling and bolstering the undead. Creatures that are trained in Performance can spend one action to attempt to play a tune.
Dead Organ (7-8).disable: @Check[thievery|dc:28|name:Stopper the Pipes SC|traits:magical,necromancy] (expert) to stopper the pipes. Each pipe stoppered imparts a stacking -1 circumstance penalty to Performance checks with the organ. Once four pipes have been stoppered, the organ ceases to function.

action->Play a Tune.name: Play a Tune
action->Play a Tune.description:
Trigger An adjacent creature attempts to play the organ

Effect The performer makes a @Check[performance|dc:24|name:Play the Dead Organ Keyboard|traits:magical,necromancy,keyboard] check.

Critical Success As success, and all other creatures who attempt to perform on the dead organ suffer a -1 status penalty to Play a Tune for 1 round.

Success Creatures within 100 feet of the organ are subjected to one of the following effects, as chosen by the performer:

  • Bolster (auditory, necromancy): Mindless undead within range gain a +1 status bonus to attack and damage rolls for 1 round.
  • Dance (auditory, move, necromancy): Mindless undead within range Stride up to 15 feet in the same cardinal direction. All targets move the same distance. If impeded, they move as far as possible, then stop.
  • Discordant Blast (auditory, evocation, sonic): All living creatures within 10 feet of the organ except the performer suffer @Damage[(2d8+9)[sonic]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:24|basic|name:Discordant Blast|traits:auditory,evocation,magical,sonic,necromancy] save). On a failure or critical failure, a creature is also pushed 15 feet away from the organ.
  • Swing (attack, auditory, flourish, necromancy): Mindless undead within range make a Strike in the same relative cardinal direction. This Strike doesn't count toward the undead creatures' multiple attack penalty, and their multiple attack penalty doesn't apply to this Strike.
  • Weaken (auditory, necromancy): Mindless undead within range suffer a -1 status penalty to attack and damage rolls for 1 round.

Critical Failure The player alone experiences the effects of a discordant blast.

Deadfall Trap (1-2).name: Deadfall Trap (1-2)
Deadfall Trap (1-2).descriptionHazard: A large tree has been cut down and supported only by a rope.
Deadfall Trap (1-2).disable: The trap cannot be disabled in advance.

action->Deadfall.name: Deadfall
action->Deadfall.description:
Trigger The squirrel swam finishes chewing through the rope at the beginning of its turn

Effect The tree drops 10 feet in front of the wagon, blocking the road. The tree deals @Damage[2d8[bludgeoning]] damage to anyone beneath the tree when it drops and pushes them out of its space in a random direction. A creature that succeeds at a @Check[reflex|dc:18|traits:damaging-effect,hazard,mechanical,trap] save takes no damage and rolls out of the way in a random direction. On a critical success, it can choose the direction. Mounted creatures do not attempt a save unless their mount attempts a save and fails. If a mounted creature's mount fails the save, the mounted creature can attempt its own @Check[reflex|dc:18|name:Mounted Deadfall|traits:damaging-effect,hazard,mechanical,trap] save by leaping off its mount, taking @Damage[1d4[bludgeoning]] damage from the fall. This damage is taken whether the save is successful or not.

Deadfall Trap (3-4).name: Deadfall Trap (3-4)
Deadfall Trap (3-4).descriptionHazard: A large tree has been cut down and supported only by a rope.
Deadfall Trap (3-4).disable: The trap cannot be disabled in advance (unless the PCs are able to out stealth Vengeant Thorn and sneak up on him before the wagon reaches the target zone).

action->Deadfall.name: Deadfall
action->Deadfall.description:
Trigger Vengeant Thorn releases the rope when the wagon is 10 feet away from the target zone

Effect The tree drops 10 feet in front of the wagon, blocking the road. The tree deals @Damage[3d12[bludgeoning]] damage to anyone beneath the tree when it drops and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilizes} them. A creature that succeeds at a @Check[reflex|dc:20|traits:damaging-effect,hazard,mechanical,trap] save takes half damage and is not immobilized, instead rolling out of the way in a random direction. On a critical success, it can choose the direction. Mounted creatures do not attempt a save unless their mount attempts a save and fails. If a mounted creature's mount fails the save, the mounted creature can attempt its own @Check[reflex|dc:18|name:Mounted Deadfall|traits:damaging-effect,hazard,mechanical,trap] save by leaping off its mount, taking @Damage[1d4[bludgeoning]] damage from the fall. This damage is taken whether the save is successful or not.

Deeply Flawed Ritual.name: Deeply Flawed Ritual
Deeply Flawed Ritual.descriptionHazard: A flawed ritual emits surges of shadowy energy and opens tiny breaches into the Shadow Plane.
Deeply Flawed Ritual.disable:
Seven flaws have appeared in the ritual circle, dancing like shadowy flames. Each of Tavvar's three aides keeps one flaw under control as long as they are alive, while Tavvar herself staves off the ritual's implosion as listed in the ritual anchor ability below.

Each flaw can be repaired with a successful @Check[occultism|dc:24] check or DC 20 (trained) check using a skill related to the flaw's original cause (see the table below). Regardless of success or failure, a PC who attempts an Occultism check to disable the hazard learns the cause of the flaws and the skills that can be used to overcome it.

Each success on a check to repair a flaw using these other skills reduces the DC of the Occultism check to repair a flaw by 2. Instead of using skill checks, the PCs can use force to stabilize the ritual. A PC who defeats a shadow wisp automatically repairs one flaw.

d4 Cause of Flaw Skills to Overcome
1 Harried (a "publish or perish" culture at the College of Mystery led to Tavvar cutting corners in the ritual's execution, so some runes aren't drawn quite right) @Check[arcana|dc:20] (trained) or @Check[thievery|dc:20] (trained)
2 Misplaced Affection (Tavvar is from Nidal and subconsciously hopes the ritual will show that there is some good in her homeland; she included some Shadowtongue in the runes and it's enhancing the energy @Check[society|dc:20] (trained) or @Check[religion|dc:20] (trained)
3 Cloistered (Tavvar hasn't done much field work and made a dangerous mistake in which mushrooms she used in the ink for the runes) @Check[crafting|dc:20] (trained) or @Check[nature|dc:20] (trained)
4 Restrained (Tavvar's own hesitation and self-doubt has led to the ritual slipping out of her control) @Check[deception|dc:20] (trained) or @Check[diplomacy|dc:20] (trained)
Deeply Flawed Ritual.routine:
(1 action) On each of its turns, the ritual lets out a surge of shadowy energy, dealing @Damage[4d6[void]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:22|basic|name:Flawed Ritual] save) to each character who participated in ritual the past round (including Tavvar and her aides as well as any PC who attempted a skill check to disable the hazard). A non-participant can step in front of a participant as a reaction. This blocks the damage from the ritual caster, but the non-participant must then attempt the Fortitude save.

In addition to dealing damage, the ritual's surge of energy brings a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pfs-season-1-bestiary.Actor.3fctnHmcLQM3KrZj]{Greater Shadow Wisp} into the room. Wisps act at the end of the ritual's turn. If there are already two shadow wisps in the room, instead of creating a new wisp, the ritual restores @Damage[10[healing]] Hit Points to each wisp.

action->Ritual Anchor.name: Ritual Anchor
action->Ritual Anchor.description: If Tavvar dies, the ritual immediately ends disastrously. With a loud pop, it explodes, inflicting an additional surge of shadowy energy on every creature in area B5 before dissipating. This ends the ritual but does not remove any shadows that are already in the room.

Dehydrated Krooth.name: Dehydrated Krooth
Dehydrated Krooth.allSavesBonus: +4 status bonus to all saves vs. Fear

action->+4 Status to All Saves vs. Fear.name: +4 Status to All Saves vs. Fear

action->Pain Frenzy.name: Pain Frenzy
action->Pain Frenzy.description:
Whenever the krooth is damaged by a critical hit, it gains a +2 status bonus to attack and damage rolls until the end of its next turn. It can't use reactions while this frenzy lasts.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.tJx9B2e3AET6PbJD]{Effect: Pain Frenzy}

action->Poison Tooth.name: Poison Tooth
action->Poison Tooth.description:
Requirements The krooth damaged a creature with its jaws Strike on its most recent action this turn

Effect The krooth snaps off one of its teeth in the creature it hit. The creature takes @Damage[1d6[bleed]] and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}. Neither the persistent bleed damage nor the drained condition can be healed while the tooth remains. Removing the tooth safely requires a successful @Check[medicine|dc:24|traits:action:administer-first-aid] check to Administer First Aid. Instead of ending bleeding or stabilizing, this removes the drained condition, but it doesn't automatically end the bleed damage.

action->Gallop.name: Gallop
action->Gallop.description: Desert Wind Strides twice. He has a +10-foot circumstance bonus to his Speed during these Strides.

Dilapidated Alchemical Golem.name: Dilapidated Alchemical Golem
Dilapidated Alchemical Golem.publicNotes:
This golem is a walking alchemical nightmare capable of inflicting all manner of painful wounds. Its ability to follow orders is granted by the otherwise mindless humanoid brain that floats in its dome-like head. In exceptionally rare cases, the brain used in its creation might retain fragments of memories or even actual intellect, resulting in an alchemical golem with a personality and agenda of its own.

Crafted of base materials and then magically animated into a powerful guardian, the legendary golem is a living construct that mindlessly obeys its creator's commands-often continuing to do so for years or even centuries after its creator's death. There exist two known methods of animating a golem. The traditional method involves harvesting and implanting an elemental soul or essence within the newly crafted host statue, a procedure seen as vile and blasphemous to those who value the sanctity of the soul; evil or amoral golem crafters tend to prefer this method. The other, less disreputable technique involves siphoning pure vitality energy into the statue to artificially imitate the creation of a soul. The result does not give the golem a true soul and is generally a more costly and time-consuming method of creation. Regardless of the method used, the resulting golem functions the same. A golem's unique animating force leaves it susceptible to certain forms of magic, but apart from these few weaknesses, it is impervious to magic and difficult to damage with weapons.

Golems work best in play as foes to vanquish rather than allies to accompany player characters on adventures. The process of creating a golem is time-consuming, expensive, and difficult, and only the most talented spellcasters or artisans can even hope to accomplish such an undertaking. While certain magical texts-so-called "golem manuals"-are said to aid golems crafters, for the most part the creation of a golem should be something left in the hands of the Game Master.

Golems have components that can be harvested as trophies or magical components; the value depends on the golem in question. Examples of components that can be harvested from golems are listed in the sidebars.

action->Alchemical Rupture.name: Alchemical Rupture
action->Alchemical Rupture.description:
When an alchemical golem takes physical damage from a critical hit or is affected by a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.1xbFBQDRs0hT5xZ9]{Shatter} spell, one glass chamber within its body shatters, spewing alchemical liquid in a @Template[emanation|distance:5].

Roll on the altered alchemical chambers list to determine which one shatters, and any creatures hit are affected as listed (@Check[reflex|dc:16]).

[[/gmr 1d6 #Alchemical Chambers]] Alchemical Effect
1-2 @Check[fortitude|dc:15] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} on a critical failure)
3-4 @Check[fortitude|dc:15] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} on a critical failure)
5-6 @Check[fortitude|dc:15] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed} for 1 round (slowed for 2 rounds on a critical failure)

action->Altered Alchemical Chambers.name: Altered Alchemical Chambers
action->Altered Alchemical Chambers.description:
The dilapidated alchemical golem's chemicals have changed after a long period of inactivity. When an alchemical golem ability calls upon a randomly determined alchemical effect, roll 1d6 and consult the following (if you roll the result of a chamber that was shattered, there is no alchemical effect):

[[/gmr 1d6 #Alchemical Chambers]] Alchemical Effect
1-2 @Check[fortitude|dc:15] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} on a critical failure)
3-4 @Check[fortitude|dc:15] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} on a critical failure)
5-6 @Check[fortitude|dc:15] or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed} for 1 round (slowed for 2 rounds on a critical failure)

action->Golem Antimagic.name: Golem Antimagic
action->Golem Antimagic.description:
Harmed by sonic (@Damage[1d8[untyped]], @Damage[1d6[untyped]] from areas or persistent damage); slowed by cold

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.GolemAntimagic]
